subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: ... I guess I ve been able to tolerate the blurring so far, and that s the difference. If the blurring has hurt me, I haven t noticed, and nobody around has
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>
> On 7/17/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...
> <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
>
> > > This approach breaks down quickly as soon as you want one of your test
> > > methods to belong to more than just one group. For example, how do
> > > you express the fact that a test method belongs to the groups
> > > "database" and "fast" while another one is in "database" and "slow"?
> >
> > I don't understand why it's important to partition fast tests by
> > "database" and "not database". If they're fast, just run them all! If
> > you don't want to run them, then there must be something wrong with
> > them, such as these:
> >
> > * slow
> > * require configuration to run correctly
> > * hyperactive (gold master, for example)
> >
> > If they're fast, though, just run them all!
>
> It's not really about deciding if a database test is fast or if a fast
> test is a database test.
>
> Groups are just a way to describe what a test method does, and like
> many multidimensional descriptions, you can find all kinds of
> variations and overlaps or mutual exclusions. For example:
>
> @Test(groups = { "database", "slow", "win32", "nightly", "multicore" })
>
> When you get used to test groups, you start to separate mentally the
> static model (what defines your tests) from their dynamic one (how to
> run them), a distinction that I have always found unfortunately
> blurred by the JUnit invocation model.

I guess I've been able to tolerate the blurring so far, and that's the
difference. If the blurring has hurt me, I haven't noticed, and nobody
around has noticed and cared to speak up about it.

> > I have yet to be on a project where /anyone/ /ever/ wanted to run "all
> > the database tests".
>
> Really? Is this really what you meant to write? Because this happens
> very often, in my experience.

Exactly what I meant to write. I've wanted to run "the slow tests" or
"the hyperactive tests because of bad configuration code", but never
"the database tests".
